Senator Bob Corker the Senate Foreign Relations Chair on ABC "This Week" with George Stephanopoulos said Trump foreign policy "is reflective of a degree of Realism". I'm reminded of "The Past as Prologue Realist Thought and the Future of American Security Policy" by James Wood Forsyth Jr. in Strategic Studies Quarterly Fall 2011. Forsyth concluded saying, "Accepting the tenets of realism is an act of humility --a rare commodity in international affairs but a useful one nonetheless. American policy makers will eventually come to it, even if they do so reluctantly...Realism is in our future." I have mentioned this in the past and will again here...Global Trends 2030 makes it clear in several places that there will be no global hegemony in the future. Analysis; American mood is finished with global intervention. Americans forked over trillions of tax dollars to support nations abroad for seemingly failed foreign policy intervention. The candidates that have embraced a non-intervention foreign policy (Sanders) and putting Americans first (Trump) have interestingly done well in the primaries. Candidates that can embrace a degree of Realism and have empathy for the falling living standards of Americans will be the next POTUS. What is more interesting is Global Trends and Forsyth both seem to have forecasted a Trump like candidate but neither forecasted Trump. This is sort of like giving your friends financial advice and not following your own advice. So here we are Liberals to our left ... Neocons to our right... are we are stuck with Realism (Trump)...just trying to make sense of it all?! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WT_5J6_faWE  For the record you heard it here first...https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/220525

News items today includes reports that FBI Director Comey will recommend to the US AG that Hillary Clinton be indicted for certain charges involving the Clinton Foundation. The original report is said to be by an established Huffington Post writer, and then the article was taken down. Normally I wouldn't give much credence to the Breitbart news site due to its partisan nature, but this story seems to have some validity: http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2016/05/30/exclusive-huffington-post-writer-editors-deleted-my-article-on-hillarys-imminent-indictment-disabled-me-from-writing/ . Its also being posted elsewhere. As a result, I'm slightly increasing my probability estimate Sanders would win Dem nomination. The article author, Frank Huguenard, reportedly states that his article that was taken down by Huffington Post. Additionally, he says his HuffPo account as contributing writer was disabled. Huguenard is reported to have written the following in the article: "James Comey and the FBI will present a recommendation to Loretta Lynch, Attorney General of the Department of Justice, that includes a cogent argument that the Clinton Foundation is an ongoing criminal enterprise engaged in money laundering and soliciting bribes in exchange for political, policy and legislative favors to individuals, corporations and even governments both foreign and domestic." This is apparently an archive of the article posted on HuffPo: https://archive.is/bERJ6 on Huguenard's Beyond Me Films site at: http://www.beyondmefilms.com/index.php/learn-more/articles

The betting market is currently 97/3 in favor of HRC[1]. It's more bullish on HRC than the GJ consensus[2] but less so than my own forecast. So what gives?  Not sure. HRC is currently favored 95/5 in California and is expected to take away about two-thirds of the delegates there[3][4]. These numbers have been pretty steady for more than a month. Nationally (for all that's worth), HRC is running about 10 points ahead of Bernie - and has been since mid-February[5]. HRC is still about 8% ahead of the pace she needs to maintain in order to get a majority of the delegates, while Bernie is about 8% behind that pace. Moreover, HRC has never been below that pace, and Bernie has never been above it[6].  So what could go wrong? Lemme see: (a) HRC dies or has to pull out of the race because of health (grizzly but possible nonetheless).
(b) A scandal pulls down HRC or threatens the viability of her campaign.
(c) Bernie defies all logic and manages to win more delegates than HRC.
(d) The super delegates defy all logic and go with Bernie.
(e) Something else I haven't thought of. As a 68-year-old American woman, HRC has a 0.013261 probability of dying within 12 months[7]. The fact that she's white and wealthy drives the probability down. The mortality rate among black women of about this age is about 33% higher than among white women[8], and average life expectancy for Americans with her level of wealth is about 10% lower than Americans with the median level of income[9]. So let's just call the likelihood that HRC will die before the convention 1%/4, since it's only 3 months away. We can double that to 0.005 as, intuitively, the probability that she would suffer a serious but not (immediately) fatal illness during that time is about the same.  What about a scandal? Last time I thought (somewhat) carefully about this, I decided that there was abut a 2% chance that HRC would be indicted by the DoJ before the election. @Kaizen has pointed to a recent piece from CNN in which we are told, "The investigation is still ongoing, but so far investigators haven't found evidence to prove that Clinton willfully violated the law the U.S. officials say"[10]. That doesn't quite put the kibosh on this possibility, but leaves me fairly confident that something around 2% is correct. Even if HRC were to be indicted, she wouldn't go down without a fight. I'd guess that there's about a 50/50 chance she'd hold until she had the nomination in hand, especially if she already has a majority of the pledged delegates when (and if!) the scandal breaks. Of course, this isn't the only possible source of scandal. But it's pretty unlikely that a politician whose been under intense scrutiny for 25 years would be vulnerable to some new scandal out of the blue. And even if R operatives have a trick up their sleeves, they're likely to wait until the general election to use it.   Bernie currently as 1,417 pledged delegates. That is an incredible accomplishment for anyone, and especially for someone without much experience on the national stage (Senatorial back-benching doesn't count) and for someone who is pretty far from the Democratic median voter of the last few decades. But he needs 2,026 pledged delegates to win a majority before the convention; i.e., he needs 609 of the remaining 913 pledged delegates. That's a little less than 67%. Bernie has received 67% or more of the available delegates in 8 of 44 primary contests: Vermont, Kansas, Democrats Abroad, Idaho, Utah, Alaska, Hawaii, and Washington. Bernie doesn't have to win 67%-or-more in *each* of these remaining 13 primaries, since he might get (for example) get much more in some states to pick up on some of the slack in the others. That's a good thing too because (on a natural way of thinking about this) his odds of that are something approaching (8/44)^13 = 1/23,729,300,000! But certainly the odds of this happening are very, very low - especially given the above mentioned 19-to-1 advantage for HRC in the biggest source of pledged delegates, CA. So...Bernie's odds here aren't 0, but they can't be higher than 1%. Call it half a percentage point to be safe. As for (d), nope[11]. And I can't speak to (e) since I don't yet know what it might be. Suggestions? Anyway, the math looks like this 0.5%+1%+0.5%+0%+I-don't-know = 2%. I'll call this 2% until someone gives me a good reason to hike it up on the basis of something I haven't thought of. So, yeah, I was a little too bullish about HRC, and I'm fixing that.  BTW, it's worth point out that both (a) and (b) apply to Bernie as well. Bernie's chances of dying in the next 12 months are 0.033997, though a bit lower because he too is a wealthy and white[12]. So 1% is not a *crazy* number to put on the possibility that he won't make it to the convention - heaven forfend. Could he be stung by a scandal? Sure. He hasn't received that much scrutiny, by the standards of 2016. The odds are surely not 0. But this is all parenthetical.

HRC's delegate momentum is slowing slightly but still above the pace she needs to set in order to get the nomination outright[a]. More importantly, there's really little chance (ca. 3%) that Bernie could close the gap before HRC arrives at a majority of the total number of delegates. If I'm reading the data aright, there are 4,051 hard hard delegates available, and 2,173 (give or take a few) remaining today. Bernie would need to win more than 57% of these remaining delegates to get a majority, while HRC would need win only 43%[b]. That should be a walk in the park for her. The only other reasons I can see that HRC would not win the nomination are as follows: 1. a new major HRC scandal and 2. something happens (this is a euphemism, plainer talk in a moment) to HRC. A new major scandal at this stage seems unlikely given that HRC has been the subject of intense scrutiny for decades. Democratic voters have largely made their peace with known Clinton scandals (whatever their probative value might be - low I think, but that's just me). It remains to be seen whether general election voters have too, but that's another matter. As for HRC's health, well, I don't mean to be ghoulish, but the thousand natural shocks to which the flesh is heir might seem relevant here, and we'll all shuffle off this mortal coil eventually. (Others share curiosity about this, e.g., @Promethean.) But just how likely is it that health might be an issue? HRC was born in 1947, so she's currently 68. The probability that a woman of this age will die within the next 12 months is (precisely!) 0.013261, as it so happens[c]. And HRC only has to make it through July 28 to be nominated (I know this is _ghastly_, but I can't stop now), so we can knock that number down about one third to 0.004420333. And when you take into consideration that HRC is white, has a very high level of wealth and income, has spent most of his life in positions of power, doesn't (to my knowledge!) smoke or use hard drugs, etc. the demographic factors make the probability of her body temperature failing to be in the neighborhood of 98.5 degrees rather than the ambient temperature of whatever location her body might be occupying in late July is so close to zero that we can just forget about the whole damn thing[d][e]. Sure, an injury (God forbid!) with results short of death could also prevent her from being nominated too, but offhand I'd say that the likelihood of this sort of thing is even less salient. Affirming previous forecast.  Super Tuesday was always going to be favorable to Clinton and she more than lived up to it, trouncing Sanders by double-digit margins in many places.  In states where Sanders won, Clinton kept pace and generally got almost as many delegates as Sanders (with the one major exception being Vermont; but even there, she captured almost 1/4 of the possible delegates while only capturing 13% of the vote).  The real upset last night was Massachusetts. 
It should have been pretty safely in Sanders's column but Clinton nevertheless managed a victory (her win looks even better in terms of delegate totals).  Sanders is certainly energizing the base and bringing up important considerations and the writing isn't yet on the wall. But Super Tuesday solidified the logic of the Clinton candidacy.

To answer this question, I use the "comparison classes" method of CHAMPSKNOW. The best comparisons that I can find are the primaries for both the Democratic and Republican parties in 2008 and 2012, on which there is complete data and writing about the campaign's momentum, polls, and delegate counts. While there are noted differences in the timing and concentrations of different nominating contests across the states and the number of candidates among other things, these are the closest comparisons that I can make at this time.  Looking back at these contests (and omitting the 2012 Democratic primary due to an unchallenged incumbent), it becomes clear that at the beginning of March, the candidates will the most delegates went on the win the nomination. With Super Tuesday today and the polls looking clearly in Clinton's favor, it seems that this pattern could follow. However, adjusting this initial estimate to factor in the current circumstances (Sanders' momentum and popularity among young and white voters being one), I would not totally rule out Sanders.  For this reason, I think the adjusting from the initial comparison class leads me to 70% Clinton and 30% Sanders. This will need to be adjusted as the primaries continue.

C Hillary has been gaining momentum as of lately, with traction in Nevada after her crushing defeat in New Hampshire. Historically, Hillary has been favored among Latino and minority voters while Bernie controls much of the young voter population. Though the primaries and caucuses have been back and forth as of lately, Hillary’s history and experience within the white house gives her the decisive edge. 
H Clinton’s recent performances have seemed to given her a huge boost in the democratic race going into the future. As of February 23rd, every major poll has Clinton up by at least ten points. In addition, about 6/10 primary voters view Hillary as the ideal candidate to represent the Democratic Party. 
A Due to the latest information on the race and with Hillary’s convincing victory, the latest prediction of 57% Hillary against 43% Bernie still holds. Bernie can easily slide towards the 50% range, but at the moment, Hillary is and continues to be in the drivers seat heading into March. 
M Recent polls continue to favor Hillary, and her 52.6% to 47.3% victory over Sanders in Nevada gave her much-needed delegates for the race to come. Hillary has won 502 delegates compared to Bernie’s 70, however, 2,383 are needed to win. But with a strong start and likely future momentum, it would be no surprise to see Hillary pull through with a victory. 
P The primaries are still an ongoing process, however logic will lead us to believe that Hillary will ride off of the much needed energy from her last two victories into the spring and certainly compete in the race against Sanders. 
S Large questions to answer: Can Hillary win over young voters, in addition to more males? Clinton has been seriously lagging within these demographics, and if she can find a way to resonate them, she will be a clear frontrunner for the nomination. Also, will she ever get over her shaky past as secretary?
K The single most key player is Bernie Sanders, who seems as confident as ever to compete against Hillary in the future. The democratic candidate seems unfazed by the last two primaries, and believes he can be victorious in the primaries to come. 
N Delegates are won proportionally based on the vote counts in congressional areas, and 2,383 are needed to win, so Clinton will need some more decisive victories in order to haul in large quantities of delegates. South Carolina will be a key area for her to bolster her lead.
O One thing that is important to note is that Bernie Sanders has been allotting most of his time to super Tuesday, which features 11 primaries and is arguably the most important part of the upcoming election. Will Bernie make a serious run at Hillary by winning massive amount of delegates in March? 
W Hillary needs to continue to ride out her momentum within her campaign, as she is beginning to rack up more and more support as we get deeper into the year. If Bernie wants to make a serious run, he needs to continue to attack Clinton’s credibility as secretary, her super PAC, her paid speeches, her views on the Iraq war, as well as her shaky past with regards to civil rights.

Nevada showed a disturbing trend for the Democratic party in general, and for Bernie's chances in particular. The numbers aren't there. As in, people aren't voting, numbers are WAY down compared to 2008. Some of that is due to the fact that the DNC seems to have utterly failed to properly train volunteers, and have made voting as difficult as possible. The caucus system in particular is just rife with stories of people leaving because of confusion, ridiculously long lines, and misinformation; volunteers doing illegal things (i.e. Iowa not recounting all the Hillary votes to see if anyone had left, Nevada letting people vote with registering, both caught on video), locations that were difficult to locate, and too few people on the ground with little to no training. This favors a particular candidate, whether it is intentional or not. And it most certainly favors Hillary in the primary (and, if I may say so, the Republicans in the general - I think if Hillary is nominated the DNC may find that they could lose everything due to independents and half of their voter base's apathy or outright loathing for Hillary). But Bernie's widespread support among younger voters isn't translating into getting them out to vote. And despite the ground that he is making up among minorities (Hispanic community in particular), it may not be enough quantity or fast enough. The African-American community in particular showed in Nevada that they are still serving as Clinton's firewall, overwhelmingly voting for her, almost as overwhelmingly as they voted for Obama in 2008. And unfortunately Super Tuesday is practically designed to destroy Bernie's momentum - overwhelmingly Hillary-loving states with large black populations. If he can't get out his support (and he has plenty, basically neck and neck with Hillary at this point), and right now the numbers show he simply isn't getting people to vote the same way Obama did, then he's probably doomed. I still think he has a decent chance, as literally every day that passes he moves a little up and she moves a little down in terms of the polls - but in the caucuses and primaries its simply not translating to the tangible numbers needed and the narrative is probably not going to be pretty after Super Tuesday, despite the fact that there will still be tons of voting to be done people may simply go back to assuming that the Clinton coronation that this race was always meant to be is moving forward as intended and not bother voting.  My own personal feelings about the candidates may have contributed to my previous overly bullish forecasts for the outsider here - and while he has wildly exceeded expectations, at the moment he's simply not exceeding them wildly enough to take down the massive advantage that Hillary started with.

Historically, the candidate with the backing of the political establishment of their party has the best chance of winning the nomination. There are many factors that contribute to Hillary having a better chance at winning the nomination for president. First, Hillary has the backing of the democratic party's establishment, Wallstreet, many superpacs, news sources and almost any other source of wealth that is affiliated with the democrats. Additionally,  Hillary Clinton has already locked up half the Democratic superdelegates in Nevada and South Carolina before the first votes are cast in either state. The former secretary of State has won public support from half of South Carolina’s six superdelegates and three of Nevada’s eight superdelegates. Bernie Sanders has secured only one, a Democratic national committeewoman from Nevada. The superdelegates are made up of Democratic lawmakers and party leaders who can cast a vote for the party’s nominee during the Democratic National Convention. They have the freedom to back whoever they want, and are not bound by the results in their states. Currently, according to recent polls, Hillary Clinton has a 61% to 34% chance of winning the South Carolina primary, mostly because she has a large amount of support from African Americans in this area. In Nevada, however, the two candidates are basically at a tie of 50% each. Moving forward, it is somewhat likely that Bernie Sanders will gain more support in Nevada because they were hit the hardest from the financial crisis of 2008 and Bernie Sanders campaign has been centered around breaking up the big banks. Some things that could change my prediction in the foreseeable future would be the results of the SC and NV elections. According to MSNBC, Bernie Sanders has employed over 240 staffers to work on his ground game, and about 80& of them are focusing on predominantly African American areas. If Bernie can effectively use his ground game to persuade blacks to vote for him, and somehow pull a upset victory in South Carolina, the chances of Hillary winning the national election will definitely drop. However, despite Bernie gaining momentum, it is still a long shot that he can pull an upset in South Carolina. Other factors that could play a role in Hillary winning the election are what happens if she is indicted for her email controversy, but it is unlikely that that will happen. Nationally, Hillary has a lead over Bernie of 49 to 33%. There are still a good amount of undecided democratic voters in the country, and how the next couple of debates and primary's turnout could have a major impact on each candidates chances of winning the democratic primary. However, in 2008, we expected Hillary to win SC but she lost in an upset to president Obama, so an upset by Bernie in this state is not out of the question, If it does occurr, his chances of winning the democratic nomination will dramatically increase. nevertheless, since Hillary has all the cards stacked in her favor, I predict that she has a 57% chance of winning while Bernie has a 43% chance of winning the democratic primary.

I have increased Sander's chances by 9 points given his good performance in Iowa and New Hampshire. Some commentators have talked about a similar path to victory for Sander's as Obama's surprising 2008 run. This is a good model, but Sander's lack of appeal to African American and Latino voters seems to make this unlikely. Sander's has started to appeal to those electorates and secured some good nominations, but Hillary has much more of the high-level endorsements sown up. Hillary also has the asset of a husband with high popularity in the African American community. A factor that has received little coverage, but is crucial, is the important of super delegates. Few realise that while Sander's victory in NH was decisive he only won half the delegates and Hillary won the other half (with two to declare). This is because around 30% of delegate votes go to a number of elected officials and party officials in each state. Hillary won all of them in NH and will likely do very well nationally. Super Tuesday is the real crunch test for Sanders. Winning in two small states, with one right next store to your Senate sate, is one thing. Winning across a variety of states on one day is a completely different story. If Sanders fails to do well on Super Tuesday his campaign will essentially be over. If Hillary does worse than expectations she has the resources, experience, political support and will to take the fight to a long-drawn out slog. My forecast is that Hillary remains the strong favourite, but Sander's has roughly a one in four chance of breaking through. Come Super Tuesday my forecast will have to revised one way or another.

Hillary Clinton has performed consistently well in the polls and has most of the party apparatus backing her. There is a small chance that Bernie Sanders could cause an upset win, but despite some good polls, overall Clinton has a consistent lead in the 'poll of polls' and has responded to Sanders by tacking to the left, securing her base. Bernie Sanders could hope to follow the success of his rough UK equivalent - Jeremy Corbyn - but Corbyn was far more successful at securing the majority of party members and faced a much weaker opposition. Martin O'Malley's polling and media presence has been very low. He remains a distant possibility largely at the prospect of Clinton self-imploding and Sanders somehow failing, while no one else stepping in. The biggest threat to Clinton is probably not one of her challengers, but something going wrong for her. Given her age and high-stress lifestyle, a stroke/heart-attack or other major health scare is a real possibility and could radically alter the dynamics of the race. There is also the chance that a yet to be uncovered political scandal could emerge. However, the chance of this seems increasingly remote given the failure of the Bengazi hearings and the email scandals to seriously dent her polling. If something like the above does happen, it is quite possible a late entrant to the race might attempt to step. For example, Vice President Biden. For this reason I wanted to leave1% unattributed to any of the three candidates, but the system wouldn't let me. The 1% for O'Malley is mostly related to a Hillary implosion.

Currently, just 29% of the country believes that the US is moving in the right direction. This, on paper would benefit BS in that he is selling the ‘dream’ and a change away from the establishment, pushing for income equality and some very optimistic reforms (free university fees, $15 minimum wages, and single payer healthcare). In regards to the latter, I think it would resonate well with the US population, given the huge costs currently. However – after 25 years in congress he has failed to get even 1 vote to support these ideas, and therefore feel as though it’s not a realistic outcome.  Although he is running for the Democrats, he started his campaign as an individual and therefore may not have as much support from Democratic voters as HC may be able to command. Despite ‘traditionally’ being a party that supports modern social liberalism – throughout the 20th century it has become very pro-business, making it more central in its approach. This is contrary to what BS is standing for – lowering the influence of businesses through flattening organisational structures and intervening (completely opposite to how America’s market based economy is run). It is for this reason, alongside an assault on corporate tax’s that he has not gained funding from large institutions (as HC has been able to do), and instead had to rely on individuals and smaller donors – a source that could potentially dry up as they run out of resources. This is different to how HC has run – with huge support from influential businesses / people / groups and unfortunate as it is – this is what has historically helped other win elections.  Despite being ahead going into the IOWA and NJ polls, he got wiped out in South Carolina which has a demographic more representative of the population with many minorities. HC has shown huge support for Obama recently (tactical I would assume, as 47% of Americans approve of the job he is doing), and this may help her gain amongst these minorities of whom have the power to sway polls  With the geopolitical environment encountering new issues every single day, HC offers more experience whilst holding certain imperialist principles (she was a key member of the panel that helped certify the Bin Laden raid) and this will take many hearts at the moment of whom are worried about their national security. She has also shown to be a fantastic debater – often attacking sanders in a show of power.  The IOWA and NJ polls on the 1st and 6th Feb will determine the outcome of this election, and with the ‘Des Moines Register’ – a key IOWA newspaper recently endorsing HC over BS saying ‘’The presidency is not an entry level position – whomever is sworn into office next January must demonstrate a deep understanding of the issues facing America and also possess the diplomatic skills that enable presidents to get things done’. On the other hand, BS is doing well among people who say they would be caucusing for the first time. The challenge for BS will be teaching newcomers the mechanics of the caucuses which requires a campaign to invest in training / outreach ect… and at present, BS has $27.3m has in hand – compared to HC’s $33m.  The 2 options are therefore BS who is offering a ‘dream’ to regular American, and a move away from the current political climate, or HC who is pushing to build upon Obama’s time in office. With the economy currently nearing full employment, with surging home sales, and increasing savings rates - I don’t see there being a huge amount of reason to make drastic changes.  That said – I will be monitoring the political and economical landscape and altering my forecast accordingly!

Polity: Bernie Sanders has two shots to make a statement and prove he can win. If he doesn't show that in Iowa and/or New Hampshire, his campaign will lose its momentum in the primaries in the southern states where Hillary Clinton's supporters are the clear majority.
Policies: Sanders is the heart of the Democratic Party, Clinton its mind. Both are credible choices for a party (although "heart" candidates tend to do worse in general elections, both in America and abroad).
Politics: Hillary Clinton has the clear edge in most relevant attributes: She is more electable, better funded and the better debater. The only category in which she does not crush Bernie Sanders is the ability to excite her party. However, she is still very well liked among Democrats and presents them with the opportunity to make the first woman president.
Bottom line: Hillary Clinton remains the clear favorite. Bernie Sanders needs a lot of "if"s to make his bid a successful one. Martin O'Malley's campaign never gathered any momentum and is de facto dead.

*Clinton's broad base of support and history in politics, along with her support from the traditional democrat power players, seems to give her all but a lock on the nomination.
